title: Passenger ‘heard screams’ after bus overturned ‘trapping 20’
text:
Twenty people were left trapped inside the bus when it overturned (Picture: PA/SplashNews)

A passenger says he heard screams after a double decker bus overturned, leaving up to 20 people trapped inside.

Bruce Daka, 24, recalled how he had to ‘clamber over’ unconscious people as he bled heavily from his wrist after the bus overturned in Devon on the A385 between Totnes and Paignton just before 11am yesterday.

Bruce says he was in total shock after the crash and was trapped on board for ten minutes before he was able to escape through a smashed window.

He praised the emergency services for doing ‘an amazing job’.

Bruce had been travelling from Paignton to Plymouth to visit some family members when the incident happened.

He said: ‘It all happened within about five seconds. I heard screams over my music and the bus started shaking.

‘At first I thought it was just a bit of bumpy ground, but then I felt the momentum switch and the next thing I knew we had hit the floor.

The scene of the accident after emergency services rushed to the scene (Picture: Splash News)

‘I think people on the lower floor and at the front knew what was happening.’

Bruce said people had fallen on top of him and that he had fallen on top of an older man after the bus overturned.

He added: ‘Eventually I got out of the front window on the top of the bus. I had to place my legs over some people still stuck. Some were unconscious, I just kept hoping they were going to be OK.’

Bruce said the police, fire and ambulance services were on the scene quickly.

The incident happened on the A385 between Totnes and Paignton in Devon yesterday morning (Picture: Splash News)

Bruce Daka, 24, praised the emergency services for doing ‘an amazing job’ (Picture: Sgt Olly Tayler / SWNS)

He said: ‘They was so fast, the place was full of emergency services within about 10 minutes.

‘They had to prioritise who they treated as some people were worse than others.

‘I was taken to Torbay Hospital in a police van with a few others. They stitched me up and then my parents came to collect me from the hospital.

‘It was a minor injury really, not enough to stay overnight.’

A Stagecoach South West spokesman said: ‘We can confirm the vehicle was driven by a fully trained and fully qualified driver.’
